channel.title: MATCH dialect (name conflict with Ren-C)
channel.description:
Ren-C's MATCH is a [powerful variadic filtering function](https://trello.com/c/LR9PzUS3/125-match-filters-values-based-on-type-tests-or-arbitrary-function-filters) for values, which can even let you just call the filter function on an argument while extracting that argument as the result:
>> match parse "aaa" [some "a"] == "aaa" ;-- whoa! how'd it do that? >:-)
In any case, that name conflicts with MATCH in QuarterMaster, which is different:
match ["three" two 1] [ one: integer! two: opt 'two three: some string! four: any issue! ] == make object! [ one: 1 two: 'two three: ["three"] four: _ ;-- e.g. none ]
This seems [a lot like DELECT](https://github.com/revault/rebol-wiki/wiki/Delect), which was discussed recently. I'd be interested to understand the differences, and if the two could be merged. If so, I think it would probably be good to change the name to not conflict with Ren-C's MATCH, because that is something I think people are really going to want to use (once they realize how great it is!) :-)
Source code for QuarterMaster MATCH is here:
https://github.com/rgchris/QuarterMaster/blob/0c5f58ff77af31572de5cc76cda9c08c11163d56/qm.r#L1390

item.title: MATCH dialect (name conflict with Ren-C)
item.dc:creator: iArnold
item.description:
Naming of functions like this is a problem. With 'match I think of two things that do or do not match, that can be there are equal or they do share some common ability.
DELECT afaik does not exist as a true word in English. DEcode diaLECT. What it is doing, as I understand it, like your 'match also, is kind of (re)ordering the arguments.
I suggest that the name of this (or the new) function reflects more this behaviour.
Some suggestions are REORDER CATALOG CODIFY LINE-UP
(As always wordhippo.com is my friend here).

item.dc:creator: hostilefork
item.description:
Ren-C's MATCH is a powerful variadic filtering function for values, which can even let you just call the filter function on an argument while extracting that argument as the result:

>> match parse "aaa" [some "a"]
== "aaa" ;-- whoa! how'd it do that? >:-)

In any case, that name conflicts with MATCH in QuarterMaster, which is different:

match ["three" two 1] [
    one: integer!
    two: opt 'two
    three: some string!
    four: any issue!
]

    two: 'two
    three: ["three"]
    four: _ ;-- e.g. none
]

This seems a lot like DELECT, which was discussed recently. I'd be interested to understand the differences, and if the two could be merged.
